channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Bold, beautiful, and… brainy? Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: With all the knowledge in your big, beautiful brain, it’s time to join a company that appreciates your breadth of experience. Our client provides online trading services and with offices in Dubai, Malta, and Malaysia, they’ve got the global reach that may provide the challenge you’re looking for. A seasoned Perl pro is just what their team needs as they expand, and that’s where you come in!

item.title: C, C++, and Perl Software Engineers, Let’s Keep the Internet Safe. UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: A leading digital safeguarding solutions provider is looking for a software engineer experienced in C, C++, or Perl. You’ll have strong Linux knowledge and a methodical approach to problem solving that you use to investigate, replicate, and address customer issues. Your keen understanding of firewalls, proxies, Iptables, Squid, VPNs/IPSec and HTTP(S) will be key to your success at this company.

item.title: Perl to Node Cross-training? Yes Please! UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 202
item.description: Simon gone into the finer details this week, you don't want to miss it. Well done.

item.title: Consecutive Valley
item.description: Roger choosen Raku and Rust this week to talk about in the blog post. Highly recommended if you Raku/Rust fan.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #202
item.description: Use of finite state mmachine to solve the Widest Valley task is interesting. Well done.

item.title: Three odd things in the valleys
item.description: Cool one-liner in Perl and interesting task analysis. Great work.

item.title: nested loops everywhere!
item.description: We not have Raku magic but also SQL solutions. Highly recommend.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 202: Consecutive Odds and Widest Valley
item.description: Great demo of porting Raku solutions into Perl. I find it helpful to understand the code better. Well done.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 202
item.description: Compact yet power packed solutions as always. Thanks for sharing the knowledge with us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 202
item.description: Unique style of code with inline comment really helps understand the flow. Great work.

item.title: PWC202 - Widest Valley
item.description: Loved the story behind the solution. The process of getting there is always fun. Great work, keep it up.

item.title: PWC202 - Consecutive Odds
item.description: Interesting questions raised and cool solutions too in the end. Well done.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 202
item.description: Easy to follow Perl solutions. Keep it up, great work.

item.title: Challenge Accepted
item.description: Solutions without any complicated logic, using just for-loops. Incredible, well done.

item.title: How Wide is My Valley?
item.description: Task analysis by Colin is always the highlight of the week. Really enjoyed itm thanks for sharing.

item.title: Odd Valleys
item.description: Not just one but multiple versions presented by Arne with detailed comments. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Into the Odd Wide Valley
item.description: Good to see the use of Perl v5.36, thanks for spreading the knowledge.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 202
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Consecutive Odds" and "Widest Valley" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 203
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Special Quadruplets" and "Copy Directory". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Annotated Test2::Tools Index
item.description: Interesting use case with regard to skip test inside for-loop. Highly recommended.

item.title: I used... Raku
item.description: Why use Raku? Nice answer.

item.title: Add a base URL to xlinx
Color Evolution
item.description: The most requested feature of the Cellgraph is now in operation: Colors.

item.title: United-domains supports the German Perl/Raku-Workshop
item.description: United-domains now sponsor for German Perl/Raku workshop.

item.title: This Week in PSC (096)
item.description: Another quick updates from Perl Steering Council.

item.title: New Dancer, Dancer2 plus Ecosystem Updates
item.description: Welcome to 2023 (just a little bit late)! We've put together a number of long overdue updates for Dancer, Dancer2, and other parts of the ecosystem.

item.title: #602 - RIP Ben Davies
item.description:
Hi there,

I got the sad news about Ben Davies through the git notifications, being member Raku github repositories. Although I didn't know him personally but I felt a personal loss. He was so young and actively involved in development of Raku language. I found this page sharing the details, if you are interested.

It reminded of loss another very dear friend of mine, Jeff Goff (aka DrForr). I had the honour to meet him at various Perl/Raku conferences. Life is so unpredictable, it is unbelievable. I have reached a point in my life where every little things create havoc as far as health is concerned.

Talking about heartbroken news, I would like to bring the subject raised by Gabor Szabo in the last edition of the weekly newsletter. At times, I wonder how can one be so disrespectful to others. I was really sad to hear what Gabor had to go through. Honestly speaking, I only came to know about Antisemitism when I moved to England in 2000. During my college days, I never had interest in subject outside of domain of India. Although I was aware of love/hate relationship between Muslims and Jews, I never bothered looking into the history behind it. Muslim community in general in India is more sympathetic towards fellow muslims. Some may find, my relationship with Gabor strange. Again, I must confess that I wasn't aware about Gabor background when I first met him when he took my interview in 2016. I only found out later about him being a Jewish when I had further interactions with him with regard to CPAN works. He has been my mentor ever since I first met him and has helped me every time I was in trouble. For me, religion is very personal thing and I like to keep it private. Having said, I don't hide the fact that I am a practicing Muslim.

I urge everyone, please be kind to each other and spread love. Life is too short, so enjoy every moment of it.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: editorial
